Keep in mind that this is my opinion of the game, so everyone has the right to agree or disagree.
I don't really see the point in playing this game. Sure, it looks like a relaxing Heaven over there, but what do you exactly have to do over there?

I don't mind playing a game with absolutely no objectives or type of story involved, but if you can't really do anything other than walking or sprinting across the islands, then it can get rather boring really quickly. You can't interact with objects or anything like that.

There isn't much audio or sounds that exists in this game. All I could hear was the ambience of the ocean waves crashing onto the shore and some water splashing when I go into the water. At least adding some good background music would be nice.

The VR support feature is also nice for people who do have the Oculus Rift and other things.

The only thing I really liked about this game was that it really does give you that relaxing vacation paradise feel when you experience it, but that's about it. Oh and lets not forget about the trading cards to help you level up once more.

In conclusion, this could've gotten much, much more potential, but as it stands right now, I can't recommend this.

Should you buy this game?Looking for something cheap? Trading cards? Then sure, get this. Otherwise, don't.

reviewText:
Heaven Island is a simple and cheap walking simulator set on a tropical island. When you enter the game, you will be surrounded by sand and water as far as the eye can see, but the deeper you venture into the island the more tropical elements you will find.

Anyone who is considering picking up Heaven Island needs to know two things; do not expect any form of challenge, and do not expect any in-depth detail. This game is meant for a purely relaxational experience, so it is void of any form of puzzles. As well, it's a dollar game, the island is not crawling with exotic inhabitants. At the very best, you get about 3-4 different kinds of fish swimming in the ocean, the occasional butterfly and some sea turtles.

While I found the visuals of the game passable, the audio here is deplorable. Heaven Island is marketing itself as a VR game. One of the most important features to any VR title is the audio. I use a Corsair Void Wireless 7.1 headset, and I will say that the sound is 2.0 at best. There are sections of the game that do not even have any sound, or the sound cuts out abruptly. You will hear some crashing waves and the odd flock of seagulls squawking, but that's about it. The sound is never consistent, and as such neither is my immersion in this VR" game.

First few seconds of my playthrough
First thing I noticed is that the game didn't have any HUD. The World
Although the game gives off a relaxing atmosphere the doodads scattered all over the island could use a heavy touch-up. There are some grounds and woods that includes a very detailed texture (probably an actual photograph) but stretched to the core. There are also textures that are just plain flat colors. reviewText:
Having played “Woodle Tree Adventures” and “The Deer”, which are both slightly flawed but essentially fun games with a low retail price, I have come to form a certain level of expectation from this developer. Sadly though, this title fails to keep me interested for long.

While branded as an MMO, there are no interactions between players, you just see people float about in a spirit form. Even if you just wanted a simple chat, you’ll be plain out of luck since the feature was notably absent. There is no possible way to co-operate either, but in my play through there was one creepy person that followed me everywhere, I don’t know what to make of that.

The scenery is nice and the map is big enough. To explore every location would take about half an hour. For the sake of achievements you can collect apples and shells along the way, but their presence felt superficial and pointless.

If you wanted a walking simulator that is kind of nice to take screenshots with, this title might be alright, I wouldn’t recommend it though.

reviewText:
Product received for free

1. Chill on the beach and do nothing.
Does that sound like something you'd do, or like to do? Then, this game is for you. If not, skip this entirely.

There is no introduction (save for a guestbook which is of no help at all), no menu, no tutorial, no instructions, no save/load function, no settings, nothing. You are just plonked onto a beach and expected to walk around I guess.

Which, well, could be relaxing in itself. If you like open world, aimless walking sims and that sort of thing.

2. The graphics are pretty.
So the sense of immersion is there. I did indeed feel as though I had been freshly deposited onto some kind of pristine, isolated (in a good way) island paradise with clear blue waters, pure white sand & fair weather. The sea and fish swimming in it were done pretty well.

I played at medium quality, on a laptop running Win 8, with a cheap AMD graphics card, and the game ran OK, notwithstanding long loading time upon initial startup. Movement was pretty smooth and fluid, with no lags or memory issues.

3. I wish I could play more.
Unfortunately I had to uninstall this, simply because I'm one of those people who get debilitating motion sickness with 1st-person perspective games and games that involve 3D panning/movement.

This had no bearing on my decision whether or not to recommend this game though.

I hope the developer will consider making a 2D adventure version of this game, so I can play it - I'd love to do more exploring in such an environment. The visuals are most definitely pleasing - very relaxing and therapeutic, especially if you love water, swimming, diving, beaches, the seaside, ocean, etc etc.

CONCLUSION
If you like tropical beaches and free roaming with no clear goals in sight, no harm giving this a try - the island is visually well-designed and the experience immersive.

Other than that, the game has absolutely nothing going for it. The lack of instructions and inability to do much except walk around (I saw a sparkling shell and tried to pick it up, but guess what - no instructions for controls, so I couldn't figure out how to, despite pressing loads of keys and clicking my mouse countless times) was off-putting, not to mention disappointing.

Disclaimer: Game played for free, many thanks to my dear friend Unpageable

reviewText:
For a cheap game Paradise Island isn't all that bad. There are much worse games out there for a similar price, but also much better games as well. Paradise Island follows the story of the ghost of someone trapped on the island. In order to escape they must collect 70 apples and 70 shells, like some tedious Easter egg hunt. To be honest the being a ghost part is probably not true. It's just the fact that you can pass through most of the terrain, including trees, some walls and most ladders. Not to mention all of the wildlife seems to ignore you.
Graphically the game is fairly beautiful. Golden sandy beaches, clear turquoise seas and lush green trees and plants. There are several landmarks dotted around the island too. Including a large Buddha statue, a small lighthouse and a few other places to note. Travelling from landmark to landmark can be fairly exciting and gives the game something of interest to aim for. But after a while you lose interest. The island, for the most part, looks very samey in places. The same rock formations dot opposite ends of the coast, along with several small boats washed up on the shore. Pointless books sit scattered around the island on pedestals talking about some pointless nonsense that, to be quite honest, no one really cares about.
For the most part Paradise is an interesting, if not short lived, walking sim. While collecting the shells and apples dotted around can be fairly exciting, it does get boring very quickly. To be honest, if you want a decent walking sim with a generous amount of freedom, then I'd go for something else. The vanishing of Ethan Carter is a fairly good example, or if you want a game set on island as well, then Salt is a better option.
With a cheap price tag, Paradise Island is worth a go, even for a few minutes, but if you want something that lasts longer, and is more enjoyable I suggest looking elsewhere. Good Day!

reviewText:
Once you realise there's nothing to do in the game other than walk around, you get bored instantly.

I know it's not meant to be a 'game', as it's more of a walking simulator or something to play around with on your VR kit but it's still not very fun. I didn't find it very immersive due to the numerous graphical glitches and no-clipping through objects. The most annoying thing however was the fact that even whilst playing at my native resolution there's no 'Exclusive Fullscreen' option. So if you have more than 1 monitor you can still click drag things behind the game window. The turning controls also felt super sluggish and I had to change my mouse DPI because I was getting annoyed at how slowly the screen rotated.

Shells are located in some really annoying and hard-to-find areas that would probably end up taking hours whilst you're just trying to find the last couple. Apples are more fairly scattered around however.

The music is okay (in the areas that do have some music) and overall it's not really a 'bad' experience but it's not something I would pay a dollar for (I got it for free). I commend the developer for taking the time to make such a big island for people to walk around and I think that it's kind of cool that there are other people displayed as glowing willo-the-wisps.

reviewText:
Indie, Peaceful, Walking Sim.

My MMO experience.
I had been walking around the island for some time, when suddenly... I happened upon a bright blue and white orb. This orb, this essence, represented another being in this tranquil place. It seemingly hovered happily, playfully, almost joyfully in front of me. It bounced up and down as in acknowledgement of my presence. It moved away some distance and I chased it not knowing why. It stopped abruptly and I felt its gaze upon me once more. Instinctively, I knew what I must do - KILL IT! Slowly, I began circling it, in my ears unplayed music Stravinsky The Rite of Spring, my blood pumping I circled faster. I was Spock and this orb was Kirk - this was to be a battle to the death! Then it blinked out of existence.  My blood lust unquenched - I was sad.

Pretty graphics, charming life affirming quotes and.. well, that is pretty much it.
This 'game' has a way to go yet, but it does seem the developer is listening to feedback and adding more content.

I got my copy free, one of thousands given away. With the price under £1, often heavily discounted and the promise of further work being done - I am happy to recommend for a look-see.

reviewText:
Basic InformationTitle: Heaven Island - VR MMO
Genre: Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer
Developer: Fabio Ferrara ,	Fabio Mosca ,	Giulia Airoldi
Publisher: Chubby Pixel
Release Date: 1 Dec, 2015

Basic OverviewHeaven Island is basically a really nice relaxing walking simulator with very few objectives to do. The idea of this game is to relax and just explore the Island that you are in. The multiplayer side isn't all that great, but this game really relies on graphics and the music/sounds to make you like this game. If you don't like games with no real objective you may not like this game. I really enjoyed this game.

Game PlayThis game hasn't got all that much to talk about when it comes to the game play side. There are very few objectives/goals for you to do, but the game makes up for it with a nice over world to explore. There is a lot of places to explore and discover as you explore this very nice looking Island. There are few books that have some nice quotes that really set the mood of the game as well which compliments the graphics of this game and the atmospheric music. The rendering of the game isn't too great. You have to be pretty close to entities to make them appear, not much of a problem but just kinda annoying sometimes. This game really makes up for everything with it's very large over world to explore, this keeps you playing searching for more things to discover while keeping you relaxed throughout the entire experience. For me this is basically a stress relief of a game, it really helps me relax when I am stressed or angry, which really helps me get through my day and puts me in a good mood.
Score (Out of 10): 8 - Very nice walking experience, would like some more objectives to do that doesn't stress you out. This could prolong the game play and keep me interested to play it in longer sessions.

Graphics/Art StyleThe graphics of this game are beautiful. It really helps set the mood along with all of the nice atmospheric music that comes along with it. It's really good for a single indie developer to put so much detail in the game on his own, some of places on the island are really nicely detailed when you find them. With the graphics and game play together it really suits the game well to be a relaxing walking simulator.
Score (Out of 10): 10 - surprisingly good graphics for single Indie developer, nicely detailed that sets the relaxing tone of the game.

Music & SoundThis game has exceptional Music and Sound implemented into the game. There is only background music sometimes when you get to a certain area and then it just dies down and you can hear all the other sounds of the game. This works well, but sometimes I was really wanting the background music to come back up so that I could relax more. The developer worked well with the sounds of the birds and waterfalls when you get near to them. Really well done.
Score (Out of 10): 9 - Really nice atmospheric music and sounds, maybe keep on the background music constantly on a low volume.

ConclusionI would defiantly recommend this game to people who enjoy playing games with no real objective, and just to walk around and explore the area to get into a relaxing state. It really has helped me through some days when I was stressed or angry, it calmed me down and helped me get through my day.

I got a free key for this game (but I was NOT asked for a positive review, mind you!).

To be honest, I am giving it a positive review so the developers can keep on updating this, because while at the moment, it isn't much, I think it has some potential, IF the developers work on this some more. I know they do read reviews and change stuff, because the game used to be literally unplayable because of the low mouse sensitivity (you had to drag your mouse across the mousepad 4 times just zu turn around ever so slightly) and they fixed that, it's now definitely playable.

It's basically a walking simulator. It already looks quite nice (playing on highest settings), but they *need* to add more details, more detailed textures. Especially the wood textures look like brown plastic. They need to do something about that. The sand looks good, the fish are really pretty. There are too many tree-clones, there should be more diversity. Maybe also add some land animals (like some bunnies maybe, lizards, some bees and butterflies?)...

The soundscapes are nice, but there are areas in the game that are completely silent and that's something they need to change as well.

I enjoyed walking around and discovering all the little 'books' on the island (even if some of the quotes were a little 'meh'...).

I understand that this is supposed to be a walking simulator, but please give us something to interact with. Anything. Let us interact with the other souls on the island, or add a little minigame in the game (like some tables where you can sit down and play a game of cards or a tabletop game with the other souls?). The game needs *some* purpose.

So, please keep on updating this and add new things, and I will come back to check them out. :)

UPDATE 06.01.2016:

The devs do listen to the community, they have added animals and you can now collect stuff (apples and shells) around the island and in the ocean. :) I like.

reviewText:
First of all, for 99 cents this game is not worth the rage and anger that is directed at the creator(s) of this game. Secondly, this game (or should I say experience?) is quite nice. If you can get over the texture pop-ups, bad optimization or the fact that this game is far from finished.

I can understand where the designer got his idea from, he wanted to emulate the experience you will have with indie darling Dear Esther, which is a worthwhile goal but thus far badly conceived.

A few feedback points for the creator of this game:
1. If you do not feel that this game is ready, set it into alpha mode.
2. The Steam community can be a fickle flame, but they are also willing to give you tons of feedback and make your product better.
3. If this all was just a ruse to get use shelf out 99 cents, then I congratulate you on your well played scheme. But I'm guessing to the extent of your design you just wanted to create something very beautiful.

So, I'm going to recommend this game but there is a lot to be learned for the developers (and the Steam client base) for future games or sequels or updates. So do not buy it if you want a badly optimised game, do buy it if you can look past that.

I hope the people behind this experience will take it to heart and go with it.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I got this game for free, and I can safely say it was worth every penny I paid for it. I've tried to break it down into a pro/con list.

PROS:
+Good graphics - Not the best, but they're decent enough.
+High FPS - Runs pretty well, even on high settings.
+Huge map - There's lots of places to explore.
+Simple to understand - It's not complicated at all.

Unfortunately, this is the extent of the positive things I can say about this. Graphics and performance can only get you so far.

CONS:
-No story - You're given no story or explanation as to why you're here and what you're supposed to do. If I hadn't read the achievements before playing the game, I wouldn't have had a clue what I was meant to do. All that you're given are a few books with cryptic quotes about happiness in them.
-Lack of objective - The only task you're given in this game is to collect seashells and apples. There's no real reason behind it and it doesn't feel meaningful in any way. It's not at all fun and gets very boring after about 5 minutes.
-World is too big - There are all sorts of structures on and around the island, but they're often blocked off by invisible walls and there's sadly no incentive to explore them at all. Instead, you're encouraged to stick close to the water and trees so you can get apples and shells. This wouldn't be so bad if the island wasn't HUGE. It takes ages to navigate the whole thing looking for tiny little objects.
-Glitchy - I encountered lots of bugs and graphical glitches in this game. One time when I booted it up, the map completely failed to load and I was just stuck in a void. Another time, I got stuck in some rocks underwater. It's frankly shameful.
-Bad controls - The mouse sensitivity is very high and the controls aren't very intuitive. To collect objects, you press the E key instead of the mouse like a sensible person would expect. You can't really tell where your cursor is because there's no crosshair and you need to have your mouse over an object to collect it. There's no way of changing the controls or editing the mouse sensitivity because when you press escape, the game just closes.
-Easy - You can complete this game in 30 minutes-an hour very easily. There's no challenge involved at all.

This game is hardly even a game. It's the kind of thing you would expect in a tech demo, not a full game that costs 99 cents. Don't waste money and disk space on this!
